topic.title: How to do 401k Rollover
topic.content:
I want to rollover a 401k from my previous job into my Greenwell 401k plan. Does anybody know how I go about doing this? I found an interactive rollover form but it just never loads. My acrobat is up to date so I'm not sure what the issue is. I have no idea who I should contact about this issue because there is no email or number listed. Does anybody have any insight?

Thanks in advance!

reply.title: Re: How to do 401k Rollover
reply.content:
Hi Samantha.  I would start with a call to the:

  • Employee Service Center
  • 800-555-5555

I'm sure they can help.  You'll also probably end up talking to Fidelity.  Good luck!

Dan

reply.title: Re: How to do 401k Rollover
reply.content: Just an update, I called the employee service center and they told me I need to get on to a computer with an old version of IE to view the form. They cannot mail it to me.

reply.title: Re: How to do 401k Rollover
reply.content:
I was curious about the same thing also.

 

Frank

topic.title: Unable to "Mark Complete" in Succeeding@Greenwell
topic.content:
I finished my last Succeeding@Greenwell course (MicroInequities - The Power of Small), but there is no take action button above the complete/not complete status indicator. Is this a glitch for my particular profile or something other people have run into? If it is a glitch, does anyone know how I go about getting that fixed so that I can mark my training as complete?

Thank you!
topic.question: true

reply.title: Re: Unable to "Mark Complete" in Succeeding@Greenwell

topic.title: Need a Mentor?
topic.content:
I have been an employee for over 8 years now. I have worked for 4 different organizations and held various positions since I joined Greenwell.

I did not have a mentor during the first couple of years. I would be happy to assist any #newHires in finding a suitable mentor and answer any career development positions.

reply.title: Re: Need a Mentor?
reply.content:
I would welcome the offer of finding a mentor as I love to learn. 

Lets communicate via Verse that way not to flood the forums.

reply.title: Re: Need a Mentor?
reply.content: Awesome, send me an email and calendar invite via Verse and we'll sync up!

reply.title: Re: Need a Mentor?
reply.content:
Hi Frank. Im joining Brazil IBM team and appreciate your help how I can get fluency in english.

rgds,

 

Ted.

reply.title: Re: Need a Mentor?
reply.content:
Best recommendation on learning English is learn it from the stand point of conversational but try to stay away from the slang part.

I learned some Spanish and Portuguese from friend that I knew and they told me certain words to not say as some may be general conversational but some are not so politically correct.

I have learned some Spanish but not much.  Some language grammar is different but try to use things like IBM Watson Translate to translate a simple conversation to start with.

reply.title: Re: Need a Mentor?
reply.content: ok. thank you. Do you know some community to help me get fluency ?

reply.title: Re: Need a Mentor?
reply.content:
I don't right now.  I was actually posting as I would like to have a mentor also at some point.

But can be a mentor to others also.

topic.title: Events On New2Digital...
topic.content:
Hi

Where do i find Event / Calender icon in the community?
topic.question: true

reply.title: Re: Events On New2Digital...
reply.content:
Hi Ted,

 

You can find the Event / Calendar from the "homepage" of the community.  Click on the community icon on top left or go to the Overview link from drop-down navigation.  You'll then see the Events widget over on right hand side.  From there you can see the next 5 events preview, and click to see full calendar.

 

If you want to go straight to the calendar view, just click on Events from the drop-down menu.

 

Hope this helped!


Heather

reply.title: Re: Events On New2Digital...
reply.content: Many thanks Heather!

topic.title: My most useful tools as a new hire
topic.content:
These are my recommended tools for new hires:

 

IBM Sametime - Great messaging tool for communicating with other employees.

Profiles - Best place to find more information about other employees.

IBM Verse - Excellent web-based email interface. There's also a mobile version to match.

Mac@Greenwell - Rich source of information for new hires using Apple devices.

Green to Open - Provides a list of free and open source software that are approved for Greenwell internal use.

Mobile@Greenwell - All the information you need for setting up your Greenwell mobile devices.

THINK Academy - Online learning environment to grow skills that are relevant; essential for continuous learning.

forum.title: How to cultivate a mindset for learning?
forum.content: Think about a time when you felt learning was effective, or it was easy to do. What were the most important behaviors or attitudes required for that to happen? Share your strategies on cultivating a growth mindset or the behaviors, attitudes or practices that have helped you learn best.

topic.title: Learning by doing
topic.content:
The best way for me to learn is by doing.  I can do all the reading and watching I want but it won't start sinking in until I try it out.

There is a free course on Coursera called Learning how to Learn which has some great info about the learning process and what works best.

reply.title: Re: Learning by doing
reply.content:
I am just like you, Ed. I can only absorb knowledge when I uses it someway.

Spend all day just reading a lot of information is same as nothing to me.

reply.title: Re: Learning by doing
reply.content: Practice is also my preferred way of learning. Just make sure you do not follow instructions blindly and understand what are you doing on every step, then the knowledge comes easily and stays longer.

topic.title: Open to Learning
topic.content:
Hi All,

Here I would like to emphasize on what make us grow is learning... How ever we are open to learning only when we are in classroom or in conference or in the meeting. Experience learning every minute when you are in office, outside client place or at your home. Open to learning from somebody who is younger to is also make us learn some lessons which we were not exposed to.

reply.title: Re: Open to Learning
reply.content:
Heather,

 

I completely agree.  You have to have an open mindset at all times, and be willingly to learn and absorb no matter what situation or environment you are in.  Like you mentioned, you can learn from anyone no matter their background.  If you are not prepared to learn at any moment you will likely miss out on opportunities to grow as a person and grow in your career.

reply.title: Re: Open to Learning
reply.content:
Hi Ed,

Absolutely, Thanks for agreeing my insight and appreciating it.It is such an honor. Great to hear from you.

reply.title: Re: Open to Learning
reply.content: I Coach and Train Sales and Sales Support Staff.  It used to be that the motto was "Always Be Closing."  In this day and age, with the speed of change, it is "Always Be Learning."  Because of the rapid pace of Change, particularly in Technology, it is ABL.  If you are Not learning, you are falling behind!

topic.title: Humility is the Key
topic.content: For me in my small amount of learning experience, I have found that individuals who are humble and see learning as an opportunity for growth and development find the greatest satisfaction in learning. For the individual who believes he or she knows everything already, learning is a burden and a waste of time. Being humble and recognizing that there is something we can learn in everyone around us helps us grow as a team and as individuals. Humility fosters greater communication, and improves efficiency on projects or tasks. Humility is the key to opening the doors to learning and growth in whatever role we play in life.

reply.title: Re: Humility is the Key
reply.content: I wholeheartedly agree with your post. I consider myself to be a lifelong "professional student" and never miss an opportunity to learn something new. Even if it is related to a topic that I am familiar with, I do my best to soak up new knowledge and find ways to apply it to my personal and professional growth goals.

reply.title: Re: Humility is the Key
reply.content:
Hi Heather,

I think that is awesome that you apply the knowledge you learn to the goals that you have. I think having goals gives direction and purpose in life. Applying what we learn to what we already know fosters a richer learning experience and provides opportunities to gain even more knowledge.

reply.title: Re: Humility is the Key
reply.content: From my point of view you are right. One needs to feel humble in order to learn. I have usually the feeling of being incomplete, what was called this Docta ignorancia. And just that gave me the motivation to pursue more studies or going into depth and discover more about any subject. For sure, everywhere are opportunities to learn and anybody can teach us something interesting.

reply.title: Re: Humility is the Key
reply.content:
Hi Samantha,

I have never heard of Docta ignorancia before. It sounds like a very interesting topic. Is it a philosophical theory?

reply.title: Re: Humility is the Key
reply.content:
Couldn't agree more. Humility is always the first step. I had attended a lecture on parenting from a NLP Coach and he had mentioned that a person should have 5 characteristics in order to learn. Although it was related to how to help kids develop learning capability, it's equally applicable to anyone who wants to learn. Since I took that lecture in local language, I'm not able to translate the third point correctly so tried my best putting few more words in point number 3.

1. Humility

2. Curiosity

3. Ability to separate right from wrong using wisdom and existing knowledge

4. Open mind

5. Gratitude

topic.title: Anbody else have any good ideas?
topic.content:
Think about a time when you felt learning was effective, or it was easy to do. What were the most important behaviors or attitudes required for that to happen? Share your strategies on cultivating a growth mindset or the behaviors, attitudes or practices that have helped you learn best.

file.label: N2D Completion Badge.png
file.summary:
If you completed your New2Digital learning, download this badge and post it on your profile.
1- Click on download and save this image on your desktop. 2- Go to your Connections profile and click in the box to share an status update, an option to add a file will appear. 3- Click "Add a file" and choose the option to add it from your computer. Select the file from your computer and click OK. 4- Right now the file is attached to your update. You can tell others a bit about what you learned from New2Digital by typing your update in the same area.
Example: I just completed my New2Digital learning and am ready for more learning! #new2digitalgrad When you're ready to post the badge just click the "post" button. (Don't forget to add the #new2digitalgrad tag).

post.title: Take the Verse 2 Week Challenge and you could win GreenPoints!!!
post.content:
Use Verse exclusively* for two weeks,

tell us about your story & you could win GreenpointsPoints.

 

Learn about the 2 ways to win

Who's eligible to participate?

All regular employees are invited to participate and you can be either a new or existing Verse user.

 

What do I have to do?

Use Verse as your primary email product for any two weeks during the contest period.  Enter to win the participant prize by sharing your Verse story in 1-3-9.

 

When does it start?

The contest begins on July 1, 2016 and ends on July 31, 2016. Entries must be submitted no later than July 30. Winners will be contacted by August 15.

 

http://greenwell.biz/verse2weekchallenge

comment.content: Verse makes it so much easier for me to handle what all tasks I owe others and what others owe me. I love this 2 week challenge for the #newHires! Have fun, and may the odds be ever in your favor...
I couldn't do my new job without IBM Verse! #newWayToWork
Just wait until the #Cognitive personal assistant feature comes online in a few months! #mindBlown
Saw a tech preview of it back at the Connect 2016 conference and was floored... I need it now!
Nuclear level explosion... it's really great stuff.

post.title: GetSimple has Been Enhanced!
post.content:
Dear New employee,

 
Before I get started, I would just like to congratulate you on your decision to join Greenwell. This is a very exciting time to join the company, and I wish you luck in your new roles.

 

Earlier this year, we announced that we were on a journey to expand GetSimple to include not only ideas from the crowd, but also process area and business unit simplifications. This is an effort to give employees visibility to Greenwell simplification progress, both from a grassroots and tops-down perspective.
 
I’m delighted to announce that we have completed our first iteration of the new and improved GetSimple Exchange.  The expanded application is ready for your use! So, what’s different?
  • We’ve added the Initiatives application to the original GetSimple Exchange to create a sleek, user-friendly one-stop shop for all things simplification 
  • There is a new Dashboard – dynamic and visible to all IBMers, and built for you and your teams to clearly demonstrate the great simplification progress you’re driving
  • We've enhanced the Reporting capabilities to include the integration of GetSimple Ideas and Initiatives – we hope this helps you facilitate communication and transparency in your area

 

What does this mean for you?
  • Begin by sharing your new and innovative ideas on how IBM can be a more simple, streamlined organization
  • Check out the new Initiatives section to learn what our process owners and business unit executives are simplifying
  • Use the new dashboard to see our progress and what’s trending in GetSimple
  • Socialize the new and improved GetSimple Exchange and promote enterprise simplification through your profile

 

As this is the first release of the upgraded application, we’ll continue to iteratively add functionality to address your needs. We could hit some bumps along the way, so don’t be shy about sharing your feedback.  Post your comments to this blog below!
 
We look forward to hearing all of your new ideas, and continuing to drive simplification within Greenwell.

comment.content: @Dan Misawa, excellent post! I'ld like to help out with the GetSimple Exchange. Let me know how I can help your team. I checked out the dashboard on Social Intranet and liked what I was seeing from the results thus far.
Thanks @Heather Reeds! I'll put a meeting on our Verse calendars to talk about getting you to be an integral part of the team. #newWayToWork
Social collaboration bringing the team together to get work done! #newWayToWork
Please also add me to that meeting @Dan Misawa

post.title: Interested in getting more connected at your site? Then find out more about local New Hire Networks!
post.content:
Looking to meet other new hires outside your day job?  Wanting to get involved, have fun and make friends?  Hoping to learn more about Greenwell after orientation? …. then think about joining your local new hire network!

 

 

New Hire Networks are local groups organized by employees *for* employees. Targeted at employees who’ve been at Greenwell for less than 5 years, they have a mission to connect and engage early tenure employees to one another, to their work location, and to Greenwell.  

 

These groups help build a strong sense of community by organizing and hosting a variety of local events ranging from social, networking, professional development, and sports activities.  It’s all about having fun and building a community when starting at Greenwell! 

 

Interested?? Then check out the New Hires Network wiki we launched within New2Digital earlier this month to share how YOU can get involved, find your local network, and even start a new group if you don’t currently have one at your site!  You’ll find fun videos of current networks describing what it means to them (like the one below!).  And we also have some useful resources to help you get started … including a playbook guide and peer-mentors!  

 

Don’t wait … get connected with your local network or start a new one today!

You and all employees have  $2,000 ifundIT dollars to fund the ideas you believe will make the most impact, make each dollar count and help us transform the experience for future new hires!

post.title: Three things not to do this 2016!
post.content:
Social media is the main use for internet nowadays. We all might want to constantly rethink how we are using and participating on our social media accounts.

So here I leave you 3 things not to do on this 2016 and also a tip on how to avoid them:

 

1- Have poor profile information that does not represent the professional that you really are.

Tip: Start by reviewing your IBM Connections profile, use the Connections Profile.pdf|View Details to make sure you are good with the basics of a good profile. Many times people will go into your profile to know more about you and this may be the first impression that they get.

 

 

 

2- Spend time during your working shift looking at content not  related to professional or business development. This can become a bad habit very quickly, you will end up becoming less productive and constantly looking at things that do not help you in any way.

Tip: Use your social media accounts effectively and follow communities, people, blogs, etc, always having a business goal. This could be learning from an expert, knowing more about a technology, seeing the latest updates about your Industry etc. At Greenwell you can use Expertise to identify experts so that you can go and follow them on Connections, also you can search within the public communities looking for a community of your interest.

 

 

 

3- Not knowing how to stay out of trouble. When you are an employee you must know how to conduct your self in social media and of course you should never post confidential information, speak on behalf of the company, share offensive content or even worst get in virtual fights.

Tip: Explore the Social Computing Guidelines to learn how to properly represent yourself as an employee on Social Media and get some additional tips. Also, instead of arguing with people use social to express your gratitude to other employees by giving them a Kudo's Thanks.

 

We need to invest our time effectively and always try to learn more about the recent and upcoming trends and technologies to always be relevant in regardless of whatever you do. Social media is a great way to do that when used effectively!

comment.content: What NOT to do are some the things you don't usually think about, so thanks @Dan Misawa for teaching our #newHires about these top 3.
#3 is very important, don't get into the twitter wars with the trolls!
Just doing my part to dispense the very limited wisdom that I've earned.
you are being too modest @Dan Misawa, we all know you are a #jediMaster
Dan is strong in the ways of the force...

post.title: How do you ask for help?
post.content:
The other week, I did the unthinkable. I sent an email in all capital letters. This is the equivalent of yelling at people in print, but to my defense, the greatest reason for the capital letters could be embodied in the one word I repeated several times: HELP. It wasn't that I didn't send nicer emails. It wasn't that I didn't wait a reasonable amount of time for a response. It was simply that time had run out and I really did need HELP. And much to my shock, after being reprimanded for the "shouting" email -- I actually got my issue resolved in about 24 hours.  (Probably not  the behavior anyone should be reinforcing, so please do not take this as article to be about the virtues of yelling at people, even in print.)

 

But, what I did learn, besides the fact that people don't like getting yelled at, was there is a way to ask for help (capital letters aside) that make it easier for people to help you.

 

1. Be clear about  what you need help.
2. Be clear what action you want the person reading the email to take.
3. Be clear on the deadlines associated with the request for help.
4. Articulate the importance of the assistance to the overall business.
5. Beg (I'm joking. I'm just seeing if anyone is still reading.)

 

Now, the flip side to that, is that many of us are going to be asked to help from time to time. And, as a result, we have a responsibility to the requestor to respond in a timely fashion. So, this is what I learned when you get a request for help email.

 

1. Acknowledge you got the email.
2. Acknowledge the action you are being asked to take and then respond whether or not you are the person to resolve.
3. Shepherd the request to someone who can help if it's not you.
4. Folllow up in a few days to see if anything has been resolved even if you're not the person to resolve it.

 

I know this all might seem sort of simple, but given the volume of content that we sift through daily in our respective roles, I think a little reminder never hurt anyone. After all, there's no greater feeling then doing something to help another person and the business at the same time. BONUS, times two! And for those of you that might worry about it-- yes, I did send a blue thanks award to the person that picked up the mantle that was laying on the floor for a few weeks and solved my problem because he clearly united to get it done now.

 

 How do you ask for help? How have your colleagues helped you? How do you share your appreciation?

comment.content: So much great advice in this blog about how to ask for help! Don't be afraid to ask as you are getting acclimated to being a #newHire within the company. Nobody has bitten my head off yet... ;)
Just be sure you are taking notes when you do go ask for help, seasoned employees like to see you taking notes so we know you're trying to not have to ask the same questions over and over. #proTip

post.title: Change your email address (no fuss)!
post.content:
When you join Greenwell, your email address is usually your shorthand or your employee serial number. But you can change it to something more sensible, like your actual name...It's simple and you don't need to do update people on your new address. Essentially your old email address and you new one are aliases to the same mail account, so both will still work. People can email either of your email addresses and they'll point to the same mailbox. So as you use your new email address and people reply to it, your old one will get filtered out naturally. Easy.

 

Step 1 - Go into the Connections Profiles and click 'Edit My Profile.'

Step 2 - In the 'Job & Contact Info' tab that automatically appears, scroll down to the 'Email' section and click the link 'Change your internet address'

post.title: It's time to invest in a great cognitive idea
post.content:
I'd like to introduce you the Cognitive Matching Vote, a tool that will change the way you vote.

The Cognitive Matching Vote is a tool to raise awareness of the vote of citizens in democracy around the world. By Watson and its API's technology, the tool will search for historical data and characteristics of the candidates in various areas of the network, identifying the relevance of applying the vote for such a candidate.

With an interface driven by two ways: both from Q&A – which refines the indexed data bases until suggests a candidate; and also a simple search mode given by the name of the candidate, will be possible to checking the legitimacy of their proposals, trustworthiness, latest news, and even what is been said about it on social networks, you can determine whether the candidate aligns your democratic goals.

Well-marked as a potential scalable project among all democracy countries, we came to deliver the best of what IBM has in cognitive computing aiming to improve the quality and awareness of the vote, and therefore, the quality of democracies around the world.

Cognitive Matching Vote.mp4|View Details

post.title: AirBnB for business travels! Why not in Greenwell?
post.content:
We are working and living in a world which is becoming more flexible and where the economy and growth is becoming based on the concept "SHARE" which means: share information, share knowledge, share thoughts, share ideas, share cars (car sharing), share bike (bike sharing)  and so on.. Even the touristic market is completely changed, nowadays people prefer, during their vacations, to stay in an apartment or in a comfortable room which is close to their daily life, instead of staying in a big and famous hotel where you can feel just "a number".

One of the most important phenomenon in this area is AirBnB, which is increasing, conquering the market in the touristic field. AirBnB collects all the pillars of the new economy and culture, the host is judged by the guests' comments which can share their  thoughts regarding the accommodation quality and hosts.

AirBnB provides:

Value for Clients

-great accommodation

-high quality and comfortable place

Value for companies:

-provide to employees high value and balance between costs and quality

-new service: accommodation completely focused on business travels

-great savings compared to the hotels prices for business purposes, around 20%.

-great savings for example due to the possibility to rent apartments which can allow guests to cook by themselves.

-possibility to indicate, on checkout, this is a business trip, for expense reimbursement.

 

I am wondering why Do not we start using it in Greenwell?

post.title: Use windows key and windows shortcuts on Linux laptops
post.content:
If you were a windows user and now  using Linux laptop for your work, you might be missing some keyboard shortcuts such as Windows+L to lock system, Windows+D to show desktop etc.

You can define your own keyboard shortcuts on linux and start using it.

Got to control center > select 'keyboard shortcuts'

Go to > 'Desktop' category, select required action and press the key combination you want.

For example windows key(mod4)+D to show desktop, windows key(mod4)+L to lock screen.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

You can go to 'custom shortcuts'  and define your own shortcuts  if the one you are looking for is not listed

post.title: Sametime: Save your Sametime chats
post.content:
I find that I do a lot of my communication through Sametime and receive a lot of information related to projects etc. through this medium. A very handy tip I got when I first joined IBM was to activate the Chat History so that I can easily save my chat transcripts so that I can access and view the discussions again.

To do so, do the following:

 

1. Open Sametime. Click the arrow (as shown below) to open the Actions and Preferences drop-down menu, then select Preferences.

 

 

2. In the Preferences menu, select Chat History. Choose the Saving Chat Transcripts option you require.

page.title: Social Computing Guidelines
page.label: Social Computing Guidelines
page.content:
]>

In the spring of 2005, GREENWELLers used a wiki to create a set of guidelines for all GREENWELLers who wanted to blog. These guidelines aimed to provide helpful, practical advice to protect both GREENWELL bloggers and GREENWELL. In 2008 and again in 2010 GREENWELL turned to employees to re-examine our guidelines in light of ever-evolving technologies and online social tools to ensure they remain current to the needs of employees and the company. These efforts have broadened the scope of the existing guidelines to include all forms of social computing.

Below are the current and official "GREENWELL Social Computing Guidelines," which we review periodically so that they may evolve to reflect emerging technologies and online social tools.

Responsible engagement in innovation and dialogue

Online collaboration platforms are fundamentally changing the way GREENWELLers work and engage with each other, clients and partners.

GREENWELL is increasingly exploring how online discourse through social computing can empower GREENWELLers as global professionals, innovators and citizens. These individual interactions represent a new model: not mass communications, but masses of communicators. Through these interactions, GREENWELL's greatest assetâ€”the expertise of its employeesâ€”can be shared with clients, shareholders, and the communities in which it operates.

Therefore, it is very much in GREENWELL's interestâ€”and, we believe, in each GREENWELLer's ownâ€”to be aware of and participate in this sphere of information, interaction and idea exchange:

  • To learn: As an innovation-based company, we believe in the importance of open exchange-between GREENWELL and its clients, and among the many constituents of the emerging business and societal ecosystemâ€”for learning. Social computing is an important arena for organizational and individual development.
  • To contribute: GREENWELLâ€”as a business, as an innovator and as a corporate citizenâ€”makes important contributions to the world, to the future of business and technology, and to public dialogue on a broad range of societal issues. Because our business activities provide transformational insight and high-value innovation for business, government, education, healthcare and nongovernmental organizations, it is important for GREENWELL and GREENWELLers to share with the world the exciting things we're learning and doing.

In 1997, GREENWELL actively recommended that its employees use the Internet-at a time when many companies were seeking to restrict their employees' Internet access. In 2003, the company made a strategic decision to embrace the blogosphere and to encourage GREENWELLers to participate. We continue to advocate GREENWELLers' responsible involvement today in this rapidly growing environment of relationship, learning and collaboration.

GREENWELL Social Computing Guidelines

  1. Know and follow GREENWELL's Business Conduct Guidelines.
  2. GREENWELLers are personally responsible for the content they publish on-line, whether in a blog, social computing site or any other form of user-generated media. Be mindful that what you publish will be public for a long time-protect your privacy and take care to understand a site's terms of service.
  3. Identify yourself-name and, when relevant, role at GREENWELL-when you discuss GREENWELL-related matters such as GREENWELL products or services. You must make it clear that you are speaking for yourself and not on behalf of GREENWELL.
  4. If you publish content online relevant to GREENWELL in your personal capacity it is best to use a disclaimer such as this: "The postings on this site are my own and don't necessarily represent GREENWELL's positions, strategies or opinions."
  5. Respect copyright, fair use and financial disclosure laws.
  6. Don't provide GREENWELL's or a client's, partner's or supplier's confidential or other proprietary information and never discuss GREENWELL business performance or other sensitive matters about business results or plans publicly.
  7. Don't cite or reference clients, partners or suppliers on business-related matters without their approval. When you do make a reference, link back to the source and do not publish content that might allow inferences to be drawn which could damage a client relationship with GREENWELL.
  8. Respect your audience. Don't use ethnic slurs, discriminatory remarks, personal insults, obscenity, or engage in any similar conduct that would not be appropriate or acceptable in GREENWELL's workplace. You should also show proper consideration for others' privacy.
  9. Be aware of your association with GREENWELL in online social networks. If you identify yourself as an GREENWELLer, ensure your profile and related content is consistent with how you wish to present yourself with colleagues and clients.
  10. Spirited and passionate discussions and debates are fine, but you should be respectful of others and their opinions. Be the first to correct your own mistakes.
  11. Try to add value. Provide worthwhile information and perspective. GREENWELL's brand is best represented by its people and what you publish may reflect on GREENWELL's brand.
  12. Don't misuse GREENWELL logos or trademarks and only use them if you have the authority to do so. For example, you shouldn't use GREENWELL in your screen name or other social media ID.

forum.title: How can feedback be useful to learn and grow? Share your thoughts...
forum.content:
At Greenwell, we see feedback as a tool for transformation and innovation. If we know how to use it as part of our everyday interactions, it can help us stimulate new thoughts, ideas, and behaviors in ourselves and others. Feedback is also vital in building relationships with our clients and colleagues. It helps break through impediments that come in the way of delivering business value.
As new hires, you need to know how to make the most of these feedback opportunities to help yourself and the company to continually grow and learn.

page.title: Mentoring Center
page.label: Mentoring Center
page.content:
]>

Mentoring resource finder

Find the right mentoring resources for you.

 

 

Do you need mentoring for PBC or certification?

Mentoring is often a requirement for certification or PBC.

Do you lead a mentoring program?

Tell us about your mentoring program here at Greenwell so that others may find you and get involved.

Get connected!

A place to share mentoring concerns, questions and best practices. New2Digital Community

For all career development topics! Career Development

For those interested in joining LinkedIn Communities

Mentoring

Whether you are mentoring a colleague or being mentored by others (being a mentee) mentoring is a simple and rewarding way we can transfer our skills and experiences to each other while â€˜giving backâ€™ to Greenwell. Mentoring is an important career development opportunity that every IBMer can use to enhance skills and achieve long-term career aspirations.

Mentoring principles:

  • Mentoring is a key way to transfer knowledge and is available to any employee;
  • Everyone is a Mentor and a Mentee, it is simply a matter of timing;
  • While One-to-One mentoring is great, One-to-Many and Many-to-Many models will have greater impact. Mentoring is by nature a social learning act;
  • Mentoring is an effective tool for transfering difficult and soft skills, often serving as a basis for ongoing collaboration across job roles, business units and geographies;
  • You should consider multiple mentoring relationships, leveraged when needed, for as long as needed to help grow your skills and career at Greenwell; and
  • Mentoring is vital to the organization and often unique to each participant. Treat mentoring as a gift we all share.

Greenwell defines five types of mentoring:

  • Executive Mentoring: provides key mentoring strategies and programs for Greenwell executives
  • Career: connects you to individuals across Greenwell who can help you explore your career options and create plans that move you for- ward;
  • Expert: leverages your expert colleague network to help you understand and target specific development goals for your client-valued skills.
  • Social Mentoring: A social mentor can be nearly anyone who has been there before you. They connect you to your new organization for guidance on work practices, new tools, technology and other resources you need to be productive.
  • Inverse Mentoring: an extension of skills mentoring that connects newer employees to more tenured ones regarding current trends, collaboration practices and their perspectives on life at Greenwell. In addition, mentoring programs in this space help experienced employees work and motivate the new millennial generation on employees.

comment.content: Thank you @Dan Misawa for building this awesome mentoring center asset for our employees to utilize!!!

Mentoring resource finder

Find the right mentoring resources for you.

 

 

Find a mentor

As potential Mentee you can:

  • Tap into Greenwell's crowd wisdom for advanced expertise.
  • Gain focus on your career.
  • Get help adjusting to or navigating Greenwell.
  • Set and achieve your short and long term goals.
  • Discover how to create a mentoring relationship with Greenwell mentors and mentees around the world.
  • Follow the six key steps for Mentees to prepare yourself for potential Mentors of any of the five Greenwell mentoring types.

Connect with a mentor now!

This site is your gateway to mentoring across Greenwell. Any combination of the following approaches will help you find and connect to available mentors in the company.

Greenwell Expertise

Greenwell Connections

LinkedIn

 

â€œFinding the right mentors takes a bit of effort on your part, but the value of relationships you create may last a lifetime.â€�

George Bandini, Greenwell Global Mentoring Leader

page.title: Be a Mentor
page.label: Be a Mentor
page.content:
]>

Mentoring resource finder

Find the right mentoring resources for you.

 

 

Be a Mentor

Six key steps to developing a mentoring relationship

Follow these six key steps to develop a great new mentoring relationship

  1. Are you ready to mentor?
  2. Volunteer: put yourself out there
  3. Find a mentee
  4. Start a relationship
  5. Use key mentoring and coaching skills
  6. Build and close relationships

Whether in formal or informal mentoring a mentor seeks to:

  • Build individual or group capabilities, or close critical skill gaps
  • Reinforce leadership know-how and develop a pipeline of talented
    IBMers
  • Accelerate individual and team performance for increased value to
    IBM
  • Provide career insight and guidance
  • Support sellers through hands-on client support and influence
  • Create a culture of ongoing learning and collaboration

Greenwellâ€™s Institute for Business Value (IBV) reinforces that we are in a knowledge economy and every effort must be made to harness our collective intelligence. In a recent BV report, Collective Intelligence: Capitalizing on the Crowd, the study team noted, â€œHarnessing Collective Intelligence can play a role in generating new ideas and solving age-old problemsâ€�, often quicker than any other exchange. As knowledge is diffused globally, it is important that mentoring supports the global exchange of IBMâ€™s tools and social learning practices.

 

1. Are you ready to mentor?

Consider your readiness

Any employee can be a mentor. Mentoring is an easy we can transfer skills and experience to each other, while â€˜giving backâ€™ to Greenwell. We all have knowledge that we can share with others to improve performance or close skill gaps. This checklist will help determine your readiness as a mentor:

  • Sharing and learning are key drivers for you, and you want to help Greenwell grow
  • You have a passion for your profession, skills and experience
  • You can communicate for impact, listen well and provide advice to others
  • You appreciate diverse thoughts, styles, cultures and personalities
  • You enjoy a trusting environment where mutual respect is important
  • You can provide constructive feedback
  • You can set realistic goals for the mentoring relationships
  • You can focus on outcomes and results
  • You can provide information and coaching while allowing others to get the answer or arrive at conclusions on their own
  • You are open to a two-way learning experience
  • You validate and acknowledge strengths in others
 

2. Volunteer: Get involved

Register and find a mentee

Mentors are great networkers. Share your mentoring goals with your colleagues. Let your manager know you are interested in mentoring and include mentoring goals in your PBC.

Review how to â€œFind a Menteeâ€� in the next step.

Start small by sharing your basic skills and know-how with a mentee. Then work up to more complex experiences and deeper knowledge.

When looking for a mentee, check to see if other employees are interested in guidance in the same area. You may be able to work with groups of mentees.

 

Key actions

  • List your mentoring activities as part your yearly Think 40 effort;
  • Share mentor/mentee activities with your manager by documenting it as part of your PBC;
  • Update your personal profile within Connections to indicate that you are a mentor. Add â€˜im_a_mentorâ€™ to your Tags section of your profile.

What type of mentor are you? Try these examples:

  • Career Mentors can add â€˜im_a_career_mentorâ€˜ to their profile
  • Expert Mentors can add â€˜im_a_expert_mentorâ€˜ or â€˜im_a_cloudcomputing_mentorâ€˜ to their profiles.

Add as many tags to your profile as makes sense for the mentoring you hope to give.

 
 

3. Find a mentee

Mentors and Mentees both need to promote their availability and Connections is our key networking and promotional tool set. Your current and future network is key to your success at Greenwell. Anyone in your network may suggest potential mentees and mentors to you; you can also actively seek out mentees using these three approaches.

Connections profiles

 

Note: While some formal mentoring programs may assign a mentee to you, this happens far less often than connections made through your everyday networks. Donâ€™t wait to share your know-how, connect with a person or group to today!

 

4. Start a relationship

The primary role of a mentor is to help the mentee achieve their goals. However there is value for both sides. Consider the value proposition below:

The value for you as the mentor

  • Extend your networks
  • Enhance your coaching and leadership skills
  • Solicit and learn new ideas and perspectives
  • Give back to Greenwell and help build our future strengths
  • Learn by teaching
  • Increase employee satisfaction and retention by reducing a new employeeâ€™s sense of isolation
  • For more information, visit the â€œGrow my careerâ€� portion of Social Intranet digital experience

The value offer to the mentee

  • Develop and extend their networks
  • Deepen their knowledge of Greenwell culture
  • Develop their skills and grow expertise
  • Get career guidance
  • Learn by sharing and doing
  • Learn to become an effective mentor

 

 

The Relationship

  • Mentors should set their own goals for the relationship. Share what you hope to learn with your mentee. Let your mentee know how much time you can commit to the relationship.
  • Share your profiles or bios with each other. This helps you both explore how each otherâ€™s expertise and interests fit together.
  • Ask your mentees to come to the first meeting with defined goals.
  • Ask your mentees to decide how much time they are willing and able to commit to the relationship.
  • Work with mentees to establish SMART goals. Identify key mile- stones where you can pause, reflect, celebrate success, and make adjustments.
  • Discuss how objective and meaningful feedback will be provided to your mentees. Encourage your mentees to give you feedback.
 

5. Use key mentoring & coaching skills

Consider the following guidance as you create a rewarding mentoring relationship with your mentees:

  • Every interaction is an opportunity to create something. Listening is the most important mentor skill.
  • A positive attitude and showing you care about what the other person says has a huge impact on creating an effective mentoring experience.
  • You donâ€™t have to be an expert or have all the answers to create a powerful experience.
  • Active listening includes asking questions and repeating what you heard someone say
  • Providing thoughtful reflection and demonstrating commitment are basic elements for a positive mentoring relationship

Consider these communications techniques a powerful mentoring relationship:

Listen actively: Give your complete attention. Focus on understanding the issue. Notice emotions and non-verbal clues underlying the words. Avoid making assumptions.

Ask questions to verify your understanding.

Ask open-ended questions: These types of questions lead to sharing ideas and information. They prompt deeper discussions, not just â€œyesâ€� or â€œnoâ€� answers. Encourage your mentee to share specific stories about their concerns. This will help you gain insight into underlying emotions, motivation and feelings.

opinions, and ideas.

Use probing questions: Ask follow-on questions to gain clarity and understanding. These follow-on questions will narrow the focus of the conversation and identify your menteeâ€™s specific needs.

Asking mirroring questions: Reflect back what you heard your mentee say and the feelings behind the words to confirm your understanding and encourage further conversation.

Use the GROW coaching technique -mentoring relationship. GROW is the process for raising awareness and getting the mentee to take responsibility.

The GROW model emphasizes asking rather than telling, listening rather than speaking, and empowering rather than directing. It is about enabling awareness and responsibility.
Learn more about the GROW technique.

Leading others requires more than cognitive intelligence (often referred to as IQ) and technical know how. It also requires â€œemotional intelligenceâ€�.
Mentors and mentees must demonstrate emotional intelligence to get the most from the experience. Emotional intelligence consists of both personal and social competencies.

See: The Emotionally Intelligent Workplace, by Cary Cherniss and Daniel Goleman

 

6. Build and close a relationship

Continue to Build the Relationship

As a mentor, you and your mentee are partners in creating a meaningful mentoring relationship. Everything you do, or donâ€™t do, will impact what you are able to achieve.

Expressing enthusiasm and listening carefully to your mentee are leadership behaviors that establish a â€œpenalty freeâ€� learning environment. Asking questions and suggesting new experiences are ways to encourage an atmosphere of exploration and experimentation. These additional actions can enhance mentee relationships.

  • Ensure that you have the knowledge and expertise your mentee needs.
  • Fully commit your time and experience to the relationship. Share the responsibility to create a trusting, effective relationship.
  • Give direct and honest feedback.
  • Provide opportunities for experience-based learning.
  • Teach by sharing your experiences, challenges, and successes. Tell your stories.
  • Share your organizational and cultural knowledge and your network of people and resources.
  • Build your menteeâ€™s self-confidence to help them realize their potential.
  • Maintain high standards and commitment to excellence. Be a role model!

Close a relationship

Explore these questions with your mentors

  • Are we ready to end our experience together?
  • Have we met our goals and milestones?
  • Has the relationship been a success? Why?
  • Can you take what you learned and mentor others?
  • Will you need different or higher skills to to the next level?
  • How can you gain those new skills?

Take stock of the effort

  • What strengths did each of us bring to the relationship?
  • What challenges did we face? How did we collaborate to address them?
  • What were my highlights and professional successes?
  • What can we celebrate?
  • What did I get out of the experience?
  • What did I learn about mentoring that I can apply in future mentoring relationships or to improve my mentoring skills

Back to the Top!

comment.content: Thanks @Dan Misawa for helping our #newHires who are #new2digital learn how to find out about mentorship opportunities. I've been a mentor to a few of our new employees and it's a tremendously rewarding experience!

page.title: Be a Mentee
page.label: Be a Mentee
page.content:
]>

Mentoring resource finder

Find the right mentoring resources for you.

 

 

 

Be a Mentee

Six key steps to developing a mentoring relationship

Follow these six key steps to develop a great new mentoring relationship

  1. Set goals
  2. Declare
  3. Find a mentor
  4. Introductory meeting
  5. Build relationships
  6. Close relationships

 

1. Set goals

Assess your readiness

Ask yourself the following questions to help clarify your expectations and goals for mentoring:

  • Why do I want a mentoring relationship?
  • What long-term and short-term expectations do I have about the mentoring relationship
  • What are key areas and goals for my mentoring experience?
  • How do I want to structure this relationship? Will we meet in person or virtually? How often will we meet? How much time will we spend in each meeting? How can we use technology to support our relationship (e.g., SameTime, Communities, Net Meetings, Video over the web, Skype, within a Blue Opportunity)?
  • What do I expect my mentor to do? What do I expect to do?
  • What qualities am I looking for in a mentor?
  • How can previous relationships or experiences inform me? What do I know about how I work with others one-on-one? What do I know about myself as a learner?
  • How do I prepare so I can share my goals with my mentor?
  • What milestones can we set for achieving my goals? Where can we pause and celebrate success along the way?
  • How will I know if the relationship has been successful? How do we end the relationship when my mentoring goals are reached?
  • Will I need more than one mentor? How many?
  • Should I have mentor relationships outside of IBM? See LinkedIn â€“ Groups

2. Declare as a Mentee

The key to finding mentors for any area you hope to improve upon is networking. Mentors are not normally assigned, you must seek them out and start a relationship.

Put yourself out there! â€“ Share your goals with your colleagues, the people you work with and meet on a day-to-day basis. Any one can suggest, or even be a great mentor, you only need to connect to find out.

Consider:

  • People suggested by your manager.
  • Teammates and people you work with on projects.
  • Through social networking (Find a Mentor (options below), Connections Communities).
  • At learning events or professional development programs.
  • At events you attend such as:
    • Town Hall and yearly kick off events held across Greenwell
    • Conferences
    • Networking or Social Functions
    • Lunch & Learn Sessions
    • External Communities
 

Key actions

  • List your mentoring activities as part your yearly Think 40 effort;
  • Share mentor/mentee activities with your manager by documenting it as part of your PBC ; and
  • Declare your Mentee status. Leverage Connections Profiles by adding the following tags to your connections profile. First add â€˜seeking_mentorâ€˜ and then further define your requirements with more descriptive tags. For example: â€˜seeking_career_mentorâ€˜, and/or â€˜seeking_architect_mentorâ€˜, etc. [Note: Be sure to use this tagging construct/syntax as defined by IBM Connections.]
 

 

 

 

3. Find a Mentor

This site is your gateway to Greenwell mentoring. Use our six approaches to find and connect to available mentors.

 

4. Introductory Meeting

Plan and schedule your initial meeting. Remember, this meeting may be the first impression you set with your mentor, so be ready!

Key actions:

  • Prepare or update your Connections profile and have a short biography ready if needed. Connect (your network) with your mentor before the meeting to provide general information about your professional back- ground. Use this connection to explore common interests, discuss experiences, etc.
  • List the goals you created in Step 1. Use these to guide your discussion.
  • During your meeting, agree on mutual expectations. Discuss how often you want to meet, for how long, and establish milestones and measurements.
  • Plan how you will achieve your goals. Make this plan as detailed as you and your mentor agree it needs to be.
  • Agree on how and when you will meet next. Take the initiative to schedule follow-up activities.
  • If you are in a Group Mentoring or Speed Mentoring activity, determine what follow-up is required and who is responsible.

Key action

 

Prepare or update your Connections profile

5. Build the Relationship

Ten tips for a productive mentoring relationship:

  • Take responsibility for directing your growth.
  • Be genuinely interested in your personal and professional development.
  • Initiate and coordinate many mentoring experiences.
  • Examine and express your development needs.
  • Set and communicate clear goals.
  • Have high and realistic expectations.
  • Be committed to actively seeking learning opportunities.
  • Accept constructive coaching, and provide feedback on given advice.
  • Be open to new and diverse perspectives.
  • Be committed to a successful relationship by following through on actions, being sensitive to your mentorâ€™s needs and time.
 

6. Close Relationships

Know when to close the relationship

While a Greenwell mentoring relationship may last throughout your career and beyond, most mentoring relationships are relatively short and change over time. It is important that you consider many influencers, coaches and skill builders. Be prepared to close a mentor relationship when you accomplish your goals.

Explore these questions with your mentors

  • Are we ready to end our experience together?
  • Have we met milestones and goals we established?
  • Has the relationship been a success? What were some factors that made the relationship succeed?
  • Can I now take what I have learned and lead or mentor others?

Take stock of the effort

  • What strengths did each of us bring to the relationship?
  • What challenges did we face? How did we collaborate to address them?
  • What were my personal highlights, and my professional successes? What can we celebrate?
  • What did I learn about mentoring that I can apply in future mentoring relationships?

 

Back to top

page.title: Welcome to The Mentoring Center
page.label: Welcome to The Mentoring Center
page.content:
]>

After logging in, what you can do depends on how the wiki owners have set access. If you cannot contribute in a way that you want, click Members to find an owner and ask them to give you appropriate access. If this is a community wiki your access depends on your community membership, and you must ask a community owner to give you appropriate access.

Here are some ways to start contributing:

  • To change the wiki title, click Wiki Actions and select Edit Wiki. You must be an owner to see the Wiki Actions button.
  • To edit a page click Edit.
  • To create new pages click Page Actions and select Create Child or Create Peer. Child pages are created below the current page, peer pages are created at the same level.
  • To move a page, click Page Actions and select Move Page.
  • To be notified by email about edits or comments to a page, click Following Actions and select Follow this Page. To be notified about changes to the wiki, click Following Actions and select Follow this Wiki.
  • To see previous versions of a page click Versions.
